findings.title: Insecure function call
findings.description: The transferTokens function can call an arbitrary contract under this contractâ€™s permission.

findings.title: Inconsistent type usage
findings.description: Mixed use of uint and uint256 types

findings.title: Incorrect require statement order
findings.description: The likelihood that the first require throws is much lower than the likelihood that the second one throws.

findings.title: Invalid call data handling
findings.description: The function silently truncates and takes the remaining bytes as the address input value when a client makes a mistake encoding an address.

findings.title: Outdated library usage
findings.description: The old version of DSToken uses assert() instead of require() for input validation.

findings.title: Unprotected use of transfer function
findings.description: The forwardToHotWallet function does not verify the external call to key.transfer, which could lead to potential security risks.

findings.title: Unprotected access control in forwardToHotWallet function
findings.description: The function only checks if the caller is the withdrawer, but does not restrict access to other unauthorized users.

findings.title: Insufficient validation of input parameters in forwardToHotWallet function
findings.description: The function does not thoroughly validate input parameters, which could lead to potential security risks.

findings.title: Potential denial-of-service vulnerability in forwardToHotWallet function
findings.description: If an attacker repeatedly calls the forwardToHotWallet function with large amounts, it could lead to a denial-of-service attack.
findings.location: Not explicitly mentioned, but the function's logic and gas usage could potentially lead to this issue.
